# cl-micro-memoize
Very simplistic macro to memoize functions in Common Lisp

This is a very simplistic macro to memoize automatically a function in Common Lisp. It does **not** offer any facility offered in more complex packages for memoizing (see for instance [fare-memoization](https://github.com/fare/fare-memoization)).

The only content of the file `memoize.lisp` is the macro `defmem`, to be used instead of `defun`, to automatically memoize a function.

In particular:

1. The function can have any number of parameters, but should not have &-prefixed special parameters like &optional, &rest, etc.
2. The function must return a single value


**Example of use**

```
(defmem fibonacci (x)
  (if (< x 2)
      1
      (+ (fibonacci (1- x)) (fibonacci (- x 2)))))

(time (fibonacci 10000))

Evaluation took:
  0.064 seconds of real time
  0.055293 seconds of total run time (0.038780 user, 0.016513 system)
  [ Run times consist of 0.046 seconds GC time, and 0.010 seconds non-GC time. ]
  85.94% CPU
  160,842,168 processor cycles
  5,885,904 bytes consed
  

```

A memoized function remembers the cached values between different top-level calls. For instance, the second time that `(fibonacci 10000)` is called, we have:

```
Evaluation took:
  0.000 seconds of real time
  0.000002 seconds of total run time (0.000002 user, 0.000000 system)
  100.00% CPU
  2,572 processor cycles
  0 bytes consed
```
